docs.lead_paragraph: IN pet store parlance, it is called a beginner fish: even a fumbling neophyte hobbyist has trouble killing it. But for a burgeoning group of basic biologists, the zebra fish is an elegant sophisticate, a grand alternative to the flies, worms, mice and frogs they have been studying for decades.

headline.main: In an Unlikely Romance, Biologists Take the Zebra Fish Into Their Labs

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST of the world remembers Oct. 19, 1987, as the day the stock market crashed; John B. Ligas remembers it as the day he did. That day, Mr. Ligas, chief executive of Howard, Ligas, Hill, a building supplies company in Utica, N.Y., was rushed to the hospital with Guillain-Barre syndrome, a devastating disease that leaves its victims barely able to move. It kept Mr. Ligas, now 54, out of commission for more than a year.

headline.main: Managing; Opportunity Out of Near Disaster

docs.lead_paragraph: Five years of steady increases in the number of births in America ended abruptly this year, and many demographers and economists are blaming the recession. The Federal Department of Health and Human Services reported last week that 2,361,000 babies had been born in the first seven months of 1991, a decrease from the same period in 1990. Since 1987, births had been increasing by more than 100,000 a year.

headline.main: Drop in Births Reported, And Recession Is Blamed

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER two troublesome seasons, last winter's due to the recession and the Gulf war, the previous one to Hurricane Hugo, the Caribbean islands are hoping for a rebound in the 1991-92 high season. Statistics showing the declines are not complete, but figures compiled by the Caribbean Tourism Organization for the first six months of this year indicate sharp drops in the number of visitors to some islands. In addition to hopes for more vacationers, emphasizing ecological goals, the growth of all-inclusive resorts and events in recognition of Columbus's arrival in the New World are talking points in the islands.
